Award.AwardTitle: Local and global dynamics for nonlinear dispersive equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work is devoted to a broad range of problems within the field of nonlinear dispersive equations. The primary goal is to achieve a good understanding of the interplay between linear dispersive dynamics and nonlinear effects. On the linear side, the project will study the global-in-time dispersive properties for wave and Schroedinger equations evolving on curved backgrounds. This is also in part directed toward the conjectured stability of the Schwarzchild and Kerr black hole solutions of the Einstein equations in general relativity. On the nonlinear side, a key topic to be explored is that of multiscale analysis. This corresponds to nonlinear dispersive equations that evolve in regimes where linear and nonlinear effects are strongly interlaced. Thus while one might see coherent linear dynamics on a very short, possibly frequency dependent time scale, these are lost at larger times. The challenge is then to uncover larger patterns that remain coherent on longer and longer time scales.

Broadly speaking, dispersive equations are equations whose solutions can be thought of as superpositions of waves travelling in different directions. Nonlinear effects allow these waves to interact, which may lead to modified propagation patterns (creating new waves) or possibly to the phenomenon described by mathematicians as "blow-up." Many of the equations considered in this project have their origins in physical theories such as general relativity, many-body quantum field theory, surface wave propagation, and plasma physics. For this reason, it is hoped that the results of the research may shed some light on the corresponding physical phenomena. The project involves graduate students and postdocs, as well as several domestic and international collaborators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported in part by this grant is in partial differential equations, more precisely in nonlinear dispersive equations. Dispersive equations are used to model wave propagation in a variety of contexts, from fluids, gases, electromagnetism to sound, elastic and gravitational waves. The main goal of this research is to understand the dynamics and the effects of nonlinear wave interactions.

This work was primarily done by the principal investigator together with his group, consisting of several postdocs as well as a good number of graduate students.  A substantial number of external collaborators, both domestic and international, have also contributed to various parts of this project.

Training graduate students and mentoring postdocs was an essential part of this project, and a good part of the funding was used to provide graduate student research support, as well as for travel and computing support for the postdocs. Some of the graduate students and some of the postdocs were also supported by NSF graduate fellowships, respectively by NSF postdoctoral fellowships. Two weekly research seminars were organized regularly during the grant period.

Some key research topics which were studied are as follows:

1. The black hole stability problem in general relativity,

2. Geometric dispersive evolutions,

3. Near soliton behavior of dispersive waves,

4. Wave packet interactions.

Black hole stability.  The evolution of space-time near a black hole is well approximated by the vacuum Einstein equations, which lie at the heart of Einstein's theory of relativity. Early in the last century, some special stationary black hole solutions to these equations were discovered. The first of these is the Schwarzschild space-time, which models a spherically symmetric black hole. This was later generalized to the axisymmetric Kerr space-time, where some spin was added around an axis. The space-time around black holes is thought to be close to these special static solutions, and a fundamental, still open question, is whether these solutions are stable. 

As part of this project we have studied several linear wave evolutions on these black hole backgrounds, both scalar and electromagnetic. In the 70's, a physicist, Richard Price, has conjectured certain decay rates for such waves near the black hole. One of the key results of this project has been to prove Price's conjecture. Further work gets closer to the nonlinear stability problem.

Geometric dispersive evolutions. Unlike simpler traditional semilinear models where waves are linear objects which may interact nonlinearly, the geometric dispersive evolutions have a nonlinearly constrained state space. Such nonlinear constraints are natural for many physical objects (e.g. spin). A distinguished feature, compared to semilinear models, is that the linear evolution no longer provides a good first approximation for the system evolution. Instead, a renormalization process is required; this can often be understood from a gauge theory perspective. 

Some of the models for which we were able to make substantial progress include Wave Maps, Schroedinger Maps, as well as Yang-Mills evolutions.

 

Near soliton behavior of dispersive waves. Solitons are special solutions to dispersive equations, which, rather than exhibiting dispersive decay behavior, maintain a fixed profile as time evolves. These are ubiquitous in nature, e.g. for water waves.  The main question here is to study the stability of such solitons. Indeed, one expects all  solitons observed in nature to have at least some partial stability properties.
